title: 174 Phaedra
text:
Phaedra (<a href="minor%20planet%20designation">minor planet designation</a>: 174 Phaedra) is a sizable, rocky <a href="Asteroid%20belt">main belt</a> <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> that was discovered by Canadian-American astronomer <a href="James%20Craig%20Watson">James Craig Watson</a> on September 2, 1877, and named after <a href="Phaedra%20%28mythology%29">Phaedra</a>, the tragic lovelorn queen in <a href="Greek%20mythology">Greek mythology</a>.
The asteroid is orbiting the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> with a <a href="orbital%20period">period</a> of 4.84 years and an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.14. Lightcurve data obtained from Phaedra indicates a rather irregular or elongated body. It has a cross-section size of ~35 km. <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">Photometric</a> observations of this asteroid at the Shadowbox Observatory in <a href="Carmel%2C%20Indiana">Carmel, Indiana</a>, during 2009 gave a <a href="light%20curve">light curve</a> with a period of 4.96 ± 0.01 hours. This is consistent with previous studies in 1977, 1988, and 2008. The asteroid's <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> of rotation lies just 5–16° away from the <a href="plane%20of%20the%20ecliptic">plane of the ecliptic</a>.
